author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Styling Substance
description: You’ll need your ‘A’ game to solve Ryan McCarty’s Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Ryan McCarty often plays around with interesting geometry and always constructs very cerebral yet fun puzzles with a lot of musical notes — plenty of cocktail party fodder, but also good stuff for your playlist. Today’s grid isn’t laid out that strangely, but it has nine debuts, many of them tough, and some excellent cluing that also adds to the challenge. I had a bit of trouble breaking in, but I would say that this is a puzzle that runs once you’ve built the momentum.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 27, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 27, 2020.
content: A map with an article on May 31 about a clash in the Himalayas between India and China included outdated boundaries for Jammu and Kashmir. The India-controlled area just west of the Line of Actual Control is the territory of Ladakh, not Jammu and Kashmir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Judge Orders Roger Stone to Report to Prison Next Month
description: President Trump’s friend had sought a longer reprieve before he serves his sentence on seven felony convictions, citing the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday denied a request by President Trump’s friend Roger J. Stone Jr. for a two-month delay before he begins serving his prison term, despite the fact that his motion was unopposed by the Justice Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Issues Executive Order Targeting Vandalism Against Monuments
description: The order also threatens to withhold funding from local governments that fail to protect their own statues from vandals.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump issued an executive order on Friday that instructed federal law enforcement authorities to prosecute people who damage federal monuments or statues and that threatened to withhold funding from local governments that fail to protect their own statues from vandals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: How College Sports Spurred Mississippi to Seriously Reconsider Its Flag
description: Time and again, debate over the state’s flag and its Confederate battle imagery faded away. Then college sports leaders threatened to take away some of the biggest games.
content: It was just before 9 a.m. last Friday when Philip Gunn, the speaker of the Mississippi House of Representatives, received a phone call from a lobbyist for Mississippi State University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devorah Lev-Tov
title: Why Out-of-Work New Yorkers Are Starting Cooking Businesses
description: Restaurants might be slowly reopening, but that hasn’t stopped chefs and bakers, stuck at home, from starting their own side gigs.
content: In 2013, after years of working as an art director, Miriam Weiskind gave into her love of pizza, first giving pizza tours and then making them at Paulie Gee’s in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Train Your Muscles Without a Gym
description: Get to a nearby park and get in shape (safely).
content: Now that stay-at-home restrictions are easing, those of us interested in strong, healthy muscles but wearied by burpees in the living room may want to consider heading to the nearest reopened park or playground for weight training. Experts note that you can perform most standard exercises there if you’re willing to use your imagination — you can even recruit your children to help as giggling, resistance-adding workout partners. What follows are a few moves for a full-body, sun-drenched routine. (Wear a face mask, observe social distancing and use gloves or hand sanitizer to protect yourself and others, of course.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Elaine Yu
title: In Seizing Control, China Sidelines Its Allies in Hong Kong
description: Local tycoons and British-trained civil servants helped promote Beijing’s agenda in the territory. Now Beijing seems ready to push them aside.
content: BEIJING — China’s Communist Party has long pursued its agenda in Hong Kong by working through loyalists among the city’s top officials, lawmakers and tycoons. That behind-the-scenes approach was a key feature in preserving considerable autonomy for the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Milton Glaser, Master Designer of ‘I ♥ NY’ Logo, Is Dead at 91
description: He was also a founder of New York magazine, created a memorable Bob Dylan poster and produced designs for everything from supermarkets to restaurants to “Mad Men.”
content: Milton Glaser, a graphic designer who changed the vocabulary of American visual culture in the 1960s and ’70s with his brightly colored, extroverted posters, magazines, book covers and record sleeves, notably his 1967 poster of Bob Dylan with psychedelic hair and his “I ♥ NY” logo, died on Friday, his 91st birthday, in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: French Soccer’s Renegade President Would Like a Word. With Everyone.
description: As French soccer closed down, one club executive complained the loudest. Now, as other European soccer leagues have resumed, Jean-Michel Aulas is doubling down.
content: Jean-Michel Aulas has been watching a lot of soccer in recent weeks. His emotions have been mixed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: 7 Killed in Crash in El Paso After Border Patrol Tried to Stop Car
description: The vehicle, which was carrying 10 people, had been pursued before it crashed into a semitrailer on private property, the authorities said.
content: Seven people were killed and three were seriously injured in a crash in El Paso, Texas, early Thursday morning after border patrol agents tried to stop the car they were in, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Afghan Deaths Pile Up in Uncertainty Over U.S. Deal With Taliban
description: Targeted killings and widespread attacks across Afghanistan have sapped brief optimism as peace talks remain stalled.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two employees of Afghanistan’s human rights commission were killed in Kabul on Saturday as a bomb attached to their vehicle exploded, the latest in a rising number of targeted killings in the Afghan capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Elaina Plott and Lazaro Gamio
title: How Americans Feel About the Country Right Now: Anxious. Hopeful.
description: Exhausted and angry as they face a series of crises, many voters nevertheless remain optimistic about the future, a poll shows, viewing this moment as a chance for progress, one they can help shape.
content: Amanda Vibelius, a stay-at-home mother in rural Arizona, is angry and overwhelmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Actual Coronavirus Infections Vastly Undercounted, C.D.C. Data Shows
description: The prevalence of infections is more than 10 times higher than the counted number of cases in six regions of the United States.
content: The number of coronavirus infections in many parts of the United States is more than 10 times higher than the reported rate, according to data released on Friday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Conviction Vacated, but Only After a 25-Year Prison Term
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 27, 2020.
content: “Everyone in the criminal justice system failed you in some way or another.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: White Actors Leaving Nonwhite Roles at ‘The Simpsons’ and ‘Family Guy’
description: Mike Henry said he would no longer voice the ‘Family Guy’ character Cleveland Brown, while the producers of ‘The Simpsons’ said they would stop using white actors to play nonwhite characters.
content: For the Fox comedies “The Simpsons” and “Family Guy,” two of the most prominent and longest running animated series on television, announcements Friday outlined major shifts in the use of white actors to play characters of color on those shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: EBay’s Critics Faced an Extreme Case of an Old Silicon Valley Habit
description: Six former employees were recently named in federal charges that were an indication of the lengths some companies will go to hit back at detractors.
content: Last summer, members of eBay’s private security team sent live roaches and a bloody pig mask to the home of a suburban Boston couple who published a niche e-commerce newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Assaulted at 15, a Writer Looks Back and Comes Forward
description: “I’m done with shame,” says Lacy Crawford, the author of the memoir “Notes on a Silencing.”
content: There are so many upsetting things about the assault Lacy Crawford suffered in 1990, when she was 15 and a junior at St. Paul’s School in New Hampshire, but one of the most upsetting is how commonplace she believes it was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Biden’s Best Veep Pick Is Obvious
description: She, more than anyone, can get under Trump’s skin.
content: Whatever his wobbles, Joe Biden has, from the start of his presidential campaign, got one thing exactly right: The 2020 election is a battle for the soul of America. That’s not just a pretty slogan. It’s the stomach-knotting truth — and it’s the frame he should use for choosing his running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Removing the Statues (T.R. and Others)
description: Readers discuss plans to remove the Teddy Roosevelt statue in front of the Museum of Natural History and controversies over other monuments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: Honor America’s Birthday (Safely) in 2020
description: You may not be able to congregate for parades or fireworks, but there are other options when it comes to having a festive Fourth.
content: This year, Fourth of July revelers will have to swap many traditions — peppy parades, large family reunions and patriotic concerts — with low-key celebrations. But there are plenty of safe ways to commemorate America’s birthday. Here are some suggestions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Make It the Summer of the Mocktail
description: Sophisticated drinks don’t have to include alcohol.  For your next socially distant drink, mix up a pitcher.
content: Making an alcohol-free cocktail can be as simple as opening a can of Bloody Mary mix, but with a little more ambition, the home bartender can create tasty, refreshing and intriguing drinks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: From 47 Primaries, 4 Warning Signs About the 2020 Vote
description: State election officials face shortages of money, poll workers, capacity to print ballots and public trust — without much time to fix them.
content: WASHINGTON — Evelina Reese has been a poll worker for 40 years. And for the last six decades, she says, she has never missed a chance to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: ‘A True Disappointment’: When Your First Pride March Is Canceled
description: The coronavirus has led to the canceling of the big gatherings that have defined Pride. For many, that means missing out, for now, on an important moment of visibility and acceptance.
content: Colin Beresford was looking forward to the summer of 2020, and for the first time celebrating Pride among the crowds of people in Ann Arbor, Mich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Dionne Searcey
title: How Trump and the Black Lives Matter Movement Changed White Voters’ Minds
description: A majority of American voters support demonstrations on police brutality, and many see the president as ill-equipped on racial justice.
content: A majority of American voters support the demonstrations against police brutality and racial injustice that have roiled the country over the past month, embracing ideas about bias within the criminal justice system and the persistence of systemic racism that are central tenets of the Black Lives Matter movement, according to a new national poll of registered voters by The New York Times and Siena College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Activists Push for Removal of Statue of Freed Slave Kneeling Before Lincoln
description: The Emancipation Memorial, intended to commemorate the end of politicianry, has prompted a thorny debate over what the interaction between the two figures conveys.
content: As communities across the country reconsider statues and monuments of historical figures, protesters in Washington, D.C., are increasing calls to remove the Emancipation Memorial, a statue of a freed politician crouching before President Abraham Lincoln, after attempts in the past week to tear it down have intensified the debate over its value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and Sheera Frenkel
title: ‘PizzaGate’ Conspiracy Theory Thrives Anew in the TikTok Era
description: The false theory targeting Democrats, now fueled by QAnon and teenagers on TikTok, is entangling new targets like Justin Bieber.
content: WASHINGTON — Four minutes into a video that was posted on Instagram last month, Justin Bieber leaned into the camera and adjusted the front of his black knit beanie. For some of his 130 million followers, it was a signal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Hickenlooper Stumbles in Colorado Race, Complicating Democrats’ Senate Push
description: The former governor has faltered in a primary campaign for a seat that is essential for Democrats to capture if they hope to retake the Senate majority.
content: KREMMLING, Colo. — For months, Democrats have figured that Colorado’s U.S. Senate race, a linchpin of their strategy to take back the majority in November, was essentially in the bag, with the Republican incumbent Cory Gardner trailing by double digits behind their candidate John Hickenlooper, the well-liked and well-known former two-term governor and Denver mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Mississippi Lawmakers Push Ahead With Proposal to Take Down State Flag
description: Coaches, athletes, country music stars and the Baptist Convention have called for changing the flag that symbolizes the state’s Confederate past.
content: JACKSON, Miss. — A flag stamped with a defiant tribute to Mississippi’s Confederate past has been raised on the grounds of the State Capitol for well over a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 43% of U.S. Coronavirus Deaths Are Linked to Nursing Homes
description: The virus has devastated residents and staff members in more than 12,000 long-term care facilities across the country.
content: The virus has devastated residents and staff members in more than 12,000 long-term care facilities across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Frances Robles and Louis Keene
title: After Asking Americans to Sacrifice in Shutdown, Leaders Failed to Control Virus
description: As Covid-19 cases surge, it is clear many governors underestimated the coronavirus and rushed to reopen before their states were ready.
content: WASHINGTON — More than four months into fighting the coronavirus in the United States, the shared sacrifice of millions of Americans suspending their lives — with jobs lost, businesses shuttered, daily routines upended — has not been enough to beat back a virus whose staying power around the world is only still being grasped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Bush
title: Preparing to Launch: Three Adolescents Count Down to Adulthood
description: Erin Entrada Kelly’s “We Dream of Space” follows three siblings, adrift in a dysfunctional family, as they await the shuttle Challenger’s liftoff.
content: It’s January 1986. What do you do if you’re a 12-year-old girl who feels invisible and longs to be a space shuttle commander? In Erin Entrada Kelly’s WE DREAM OF SPACE (Greenwillow, 400 pp., $16.99; ages 8 to 12), Bernadatte Nelson Thomas (known as Bird) daydreams she’s reaching out to Judith Resnik, an astronaut prepping for the launch of the Challenger. An imaginary Resnik talks back, telling Bird, “You’re not disappearing,” and describes being in space as “floating in a world that belongs only to you, but also belongs to everyone else.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Edelheit and Brooks Barnes
title: ‘We Live From the Tourists’: Orlando Workers Face Virus’s Fallout
description: The pandemic decimated central Florida’s once-booming leisure and hospitality industry. Disney World and other destinations have started to reopen, but infections in the state are surging.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — Four thousand phone calls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy Mandell
title: Say I Love You. I’m Waiting.
description: Ten couples share stories of how and when they said those three words to their partner for the first time. Some awkward, some sweet.
content: The words “I love you,” spoken for the first time, are milestones that let you know where a romantic relationship stands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: U.S. Must Release Children From Family Detention Centers, Judge Rules
description: The order, which cited the severity of the coronavirus pandemic, applies to children held in the nation’s three family detention centers for more than 20 days.
content: Citing the severity of the coronavirus pandemic, a federal judge in Los Angeles on Friday ordered the release of migrant children held in the country’s three family detention centers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough and Reed Abelson
title: Obamacare Faces Unprecedented Test as Economy Sinks
description: The battles over the health law have played out during a decade of continuous economic growth. How it performs as a safety net now may help determine its future.
content: The Affordable Care Act, the landmark health law that has been a subject of caustic debate for more than a decade, is being tested as never before, as millions of Americans lose their jobs and medical coverage in the midst of the nation’s gravest health crisis in a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: After the Statues Fall
description: Some deserve to be toppled. But monuments to those who sought to make the union more perfect should stand.
content: Regarding statues, monuments, and other public tributes to those once deemed great — which to do away with and which to keep — four familiar words can guide our choices: a more perfect union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paola Mendoza
title: Brave Teenage Refugees Seek a Home of the Free
description: In Jenny Torres Sanchez’ “We Are Not From Here,” three Guatemalan teenagers embark on a harrowing journey through Mexico to the U.S. border.
content: WE ARE NOT FROM HERE (Philomel, 368 pp., $17.99; ages 14 and up), by Jenny Torres Sanchez, is a novel precisely for this moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Waking Up in 2030
description: The suspended time of the pandemic has put history on fast-forward.
content: There is something peculiar about time during the pandemic. On the one hand there’s a feeling that the normal calendar has simply stopped, school schedules and sports seasons evaporating, one homebound day passing much like another. It’s a feeling of hiatus, intermission, like the days between Christmas and the new year, or some extra season invented by a Renaissance pope to fix a lagging calendar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tamir Kalifa
title: ‘San Antonio Strong’
description: The city’s food bank has been a lifeline and a source of hope for many across Southwest Texas.
content: SAN ANTONIO — Austin Wondzell’s midnight blue S.U.V. was one of the nearly 2,000 vehicles winding through a stadium parking lot on a Friday morning in mid-May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Hillenbrand
title: I Was in Love With a Tree That Swallowed the Sky
description: The cutting of a beloved tree felled my heart. Then a bird came.
content: I bought my house in Oregon without ever having set foot in it, without ever having even been to the state. I bought it knowing I might never make it here, that I’d have to risk my life to try. In my rowhouse in the clatter of Washington, D.C., my only view was the back of another house, about as far as I’d ever been able to see during years spent largely housebound with an illness that was finally beginning to let me go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: A ‘Cure for Heart Disease’? A Single Shot Succeeds in Monkeys
description: A novel gene-editing experiment seems to have permanently reduced LDL and triglyceride levels in monkeys.
content: What if a single injection could lower blood levels of cholesterol and triglycerides — for a lifetime?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caren Osten Gerszberg
title: Missing the Olympics? Organize Your Own Games, at Home
description: Sure, the official Summer Games have been postponed. But with most people staying local and many camps shut down, you can create a fun, friendly competition in your own backyard.
content: Watching athletes compete in the Summer Olympic Games is a long-awaited highlight for millions around the world. It’s a ritual that comes every four years — a chance to escape the heat, crank up the air conditioning and watch televised events like basketball games, track-and-field relays and table tennis matches. But with the coronavirus outbreak forcing the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo to be postponed, viewers will have to wait another year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo
title: Give Yourself the Perfect Summer Pedicure
description: Getting your feet sandal-ready can be done at home. Men, you can pay attention, too.
content: After months of shoving your feet into thick, slouchy socks — and boots, if you ventured out — it’s past time for your toes to see a little sunlight. But they’re likely to need at least a little T.L.C., lest you risk offending the members of your quarantine pod. Follow this step-by-step (no pun intended) guide to give yourself a safe summer pedicure. And, yes, these instructions can also be followed by the manliest of readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Gotten Used to Quarantine? Us Too
description: Much of the country is reopening, even as in some places the number of Covid-19 cases is rising. The idea of stepping out of isolation makes some people anxious.
content: Across the country, cities and states are in various stages of reopening, even as cases of Covid-19 are rising, particularly in the South. Some people are lounging at the beach, without masks, or going out to eat and drink in restaurants and bars, where social distancing may be difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: As the Coronavirus Spreads, Drug Pricing Legislation Remains Stalled
description: For both parties, taking action to reduce the cost of prescription drugs was a banner policy issue before the coronavirus outbreak. Does it still have a chance?
content: WASHINGTON — When President Trump visited Senate Republicans last month for the first time since the coronavirus pandemic began ripping across the country, Senator Charles E. Grassley, the powerful chairman of the Finance Committee, confronted him about whether he still wanted to fulfill his years-old promise of lowering the cost of prescription drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Biden Still Wants to Close Guantánamo Prison
description: The Obama administration ran into a wall of political opposition when it tried. The former vice president rarely brings up the topic and has yet to draw up a strategy but says he shares the goal.
content: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz and Maggie Astor
title: Black Trans Women Seek More Space in the Movement They Helped Start
description: At no point have black trans people shared fully in the gains of the L.G.B.T.Q. or racial justice movements. This may be changing.
content: Transgender women of color led the uprising at the Stonewall Inn 51 years ago on Sunday, but they were never put at the center of the movement they helped start: one whose very shorthand, “the gay rights movement,” erases them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: The First Pick in the N.H.L. Draft Goes to … TBD
description: The N.H.L. held the first of two lotteries to determine the 2020 draft order but, in a confounding reveal, did not name the team that will select first over all.
content: The National Hockey League on Friday held the first part of its draft lottery, an annual ritual of pro sports leagues meant to lay out an order of business for the rest of the draft process. The night’s primary revelation, however, was that this year’s draft order is still as incomplete as the season itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Princeton Will Remove Woodrow Wilson’s Name From School
description: University trustees concluded that Wilson’s “racist thinking and policies make him an inappropriate namesake for a school or college,” Princeton’s president said on Saturday.
content: Princeton University will remove Woodrow Wilson’s name from its public policy school and one of its residential colleges, the university’s president said on Saturday — a move that comes four years after it decided to keep the name over the objections of student protests.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. States Backtrack on Reopening as Coronavirus Cases Climb
description: Mississippi and Houston are among the areas in danger of being overwhelmed. The resurgent virus has left many Americans questioning whether earlier lockdowns were worth their sacrifices.
content: The coronavirus continued its surge across the South and West, threatening to quickly overwhelm areas that had until recently been spared the worst of the pandemic. Some Mississippi intensive care units are at capacity as coronavirus cases climb and residents of Texas’s largest county received an emergency alert of the highest level, urging residents to remain at home, wear a mask and cancel gatherings. Houston’s mayor has said that I.C.U.s there were nearly at capacity. And at the University of Mississippi Medical Center, the I.C.U. is completely full, said Dr. Alan Jones, the assistant vice chancellor for clinical affairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Dark’ and a Star-Studded Global Citizen Concert
description: Netflix’s twisty time-travel drama returns for a third and final season, and Dwayne Johnson hosts a concert to raise awareness for coronavirus relief.
content: DARK Stream on Netflix. This incredibly complex and inventive German sci-fi series starts out as so many other mystery thrillers do, with the disappearance of young boy. But as the series progresses, the mystery surrounding the boy, who vanished in a forest, grows deeper and more bizarre — involving time travel, an apocalyptic event, a secretive society and the existence of multiple universes. The series, which returns for a third and final season, focuses on the secrets and intertwined histories of four local families, spanning multiple generations. As much as the show is a heady, brain-bending exploration into the physics and ethics of time travel, it also poses some thought-provoking questions concerning the nature of free will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Welcome to Your School Reunion! No Name Tags Required
description: Lurking. Peeping. Filters. Has Zoom actually improved this most fraught of American social rituals?
content: Full disclosure: I have never attended a school reunion. Nor am I likely, even during lockdown, to make that group journey down memory lane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Sarah Mervosh and Shawn Hubler
title: Leaders Re-examine U.S. Reopenings as Coronavirus Cases Hit Another Record
description: Officials nationwide were rethinking their efforts to slow the virus, which the nation’s top infectious disease expert said were “not working.”
content: MIAMI — As coronavirus cases surge across much of the United States, leaders are urgently rethinking their strategies to curb the spread, which the nation’s top infectious disease expert said on Friday were “not working.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Richard Silvestri returns and shakes our cryptic confidence.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — Today’s cryptic was slow going for me, probably because there are hardly any anagrams, and I lean on them for letters. I found the southeast corner extremely tough! However, the effort’s very worthwhile and there are some really interesting and unusual entries, once you’ve sorted your way through the multiple steps in most of the clues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: On Coronavirus, Americans Still Trust the Experts
description: But that trust may be tested in the months ahead.
content: For months, President Trump has been contradicting his public health advisers over the response to the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Tangiest Key Lime Pie Bars
description: Strawberry drop biscuits, sausage and peppers pasta, and more.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Samantha Seneviratne’s Key lime pie bars with vanilla wafer crust (above), Tejal Rao’s cheesy pan pizza and Kay Chun’s sausage and peppers pasta with broccoli. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Dr. William Dement, Leader in Sleep Disorder Research, Dies at 91
description: At Stanford, he created the world’s first successful sleep clinic and taught a popular class on sleep and dreams. (If he caught a student dozing, he’d wake him with a water gun.)
content: Dr. William Dement, whose introduction to the mysteries of slumber as a postgraduate student in the 1950s led him to become an eminent researcher of sleep disorders and to preach the benefits of a good night’s sleep, died on June 17 in Stanford, Calif. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Power-Ups
description: Jon Schneider and Anderson Wang collaborate on a lofty Sunday debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle is a bicoastal double debut from Jon Schneider, a research scientist at Google in New York City, and Anderson Wang, a software engineer in California. The two met at M.I.T. and bonded over solving and constructing together. (Shout out to any zoom or skype group solvers out there! What a world.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Bit of Relief: The Long Distance Chorus
description: How the elementary school students of Staten Island’s P.S. 22 Chorus are harmonizing from afar.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Elly Stone, 93, Distinctive Singer in ‘Jacques Brel’ Revue, Dies
description: She performed some of the most powerful songs in that show, which ran for more than four years in Greenwich Village and became a theater staple.
content: Elly Stone, who was enjoying a moderately successful career as a singer and actress when she jumped to a new level of fame in 1968 as part of the wildly popular musical revue “Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris,” died on June 11 in Cuenca, Ecuador. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Debelak
title: We Would Die of the Virus or Not. The System Would Roll On.
description: Prison officials did everything they could to prevent a coronavirus outbreak. Everything except release prisoners.
content: GRAFTON, Ohio — A few of us were talking at Roc and Dave’s bunk about writing a petition about keeping inmates safe during the pandemic. Suggestions of what to include were trickling in throughout the long, dragging day — through in-depth conversations or notes passed under the cell door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Now Is a Time to Learn From Hispanic Americans
description: They’re not “criminals, drug dealers, rapists,” as Trump said, but are often models of civil society.
content: CORNELIUS, Ore. — Scholars call it the “Hispanic Paradox”: Despite poverty and discrimination, Hispanic Americans live significantly longer than white or black Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Trump, Not So Statuesque
description: Things are looking down for the Donald.
content: WASHINGTON — For a long time, Republicans have brandished the same old narrative to try to scare their way into the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Uber Rides Cost More? OK
description: Many gig-based business models help customers take advantage of workers. Let’s stop giving tech companies a free ride.
content: The underpinning of countless Silicon Valley success stories is a method of commerce that treats millions of workers as disposable and deprives them of protections regular employees enjoy, like employer-paid health care. Keeping Uber drivers and DoorDash food couriers classified as contractors saves the companies billions in costs and has helped fuel billions more in investor value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Five Years and 100-Plus Stories: What It’s Like Covering ‘Hamilton’
description: From the very beginning, it was clear the musical was going to be a big news story. I’ve been reporting on it, from the East Village to San Juan, ever since.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery
title: Houston Moves to ‘Severe’ Covid Warning. Will Enough People Listen?
description: In Texas’ most populous county, officials are again urging people to stay home, saying this flood of cases will be worse than the last one.
content: HOUSTON — Alex Belt, a single mother of three girls and the owner of Silly Silly Girls gift boutique, has a succinct way of describing her life in Houston as officials warn of an alarming spike in coronavirus cases: “Business as usual without the business.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: Micheal Martin Becomes Ireland’s Prime Minister as Rival Parties Ally
description: The country’s new coalition government, formed across a historic political fault line after four months of negotiations, faces headwinds from Brexit, the pandemic and a housing crisis.
content: DUBLIN — Ireland’s Parliament appointed Micheal Martin, a center-right politician, as prime minister on Saturday as the country deals with the coronavirus and fallout from a housing crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: A Reckoning With Race to Ensure Diversity for America’s Face Abroad
description: The national conversation about discrimination is overdue at the State Department, according to those who have been disparaged in a culture that favors “pale, male and Yale” diplomats.
content: WASHINGTON — Tianna Spears dreamed for years of becoming an American diplomat. She quit in January after two, and says she will never return to the State Department, given what she has described as its failure to protect her from racial discrimination — from the United States government — while on the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur and Jenn Ackerman
title: Her Olympic Dream on Hold, Teen Gymnast Faces Other Trials
description: Sunisa Lee had been ecstatic to return to her gym at the start of June. Then came tumult in Minnesota and the death of two close relatives. “I just want this year to be over. I’m so ready for 2021.”
content: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Lee’s first installment here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Poland’s Virus-Delayed Presidential Election Suddenly Looks Tight
description: The country’s nationalist governing party has found itself in a spirited fight, as new circumstances harden old divisions.
content: WARSAW — Poland’s governing party swept to power five years ago by appealing to a sense of aggrieved nationalism, and moved quickly to transform the state in ways that critics contend has torn at the fragile fabric of its democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Starbucks Barista Gets $65,000 in Donations After Customer’s Mask Complaint
description: A woman who was not wearing a mask griped on Facebook about the barista, who had tried to explain company policy. Her post unexpectedly led to an outpouring of money for the worker.
content: A Starbucks barista in San Diego has more than $65,000 to fuel his dream of teaching dance after an online fund-raiser was created in response to a customer who was not wearing a mask complained on Facebook about the company’s policies and her interaction with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker
title: The Black Officer Who Detained George Floyd Had Pledged to Fix the Police
description: Alex Kueng is one of four former officers accused of crimes in the killing of Mr. Floyd, which happened on his third shift. His decision to join the force had frayed friendships.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — There were two black men at the scene of the police killing in Minneapolis last month that roiled the nation. One, George Floyd, was sprawled on the asphalt, with a white officer’s knee on his neck. The other black man, Alex Kueng, was a rookie police officer who held his back as Mr. Floyd struggled to breathe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How the World Missed Covid-19’s Silent Spread
description: Symptomless transmission makes the coronavirus far harder to fight. But health officials dismissed the risk for months, pushing misleading and contradictory claims in the face of mounting evidence.
content: MUNICH — Dr. Camilla Rothe was about to leave for dinner when the government laboratory called with the surprising test result. Positive. It was Jan. 27. She had just discovered Germany’s first case of the new coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times
